caption: Table 1: Results (averaged over 5 runs) on solving the jigsaw puzzle on Noisy MNIST and CIFAR10.
description: This table presents the results of the jigsaw puzzle experiments on the Noisy MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets.  Five different methods (Gumbel-Sinkhorn Network, DiffSort, Error-free DiffSort, and Symmetric Diffusers) are compared across different puzzle sizes (2x2 to 6x6 for Noisy MNIST and 2x2 to 4x4 for CIFAR-10). The metrics used for evaluation include Kendall-Tau, Accuracy (percentage of perfectly reassembled images), Correct (percentage of correctly placed pieces), RMSE (root mean square error of reassembled images), and MAE (mean absolute error).  The results show that the Symmetric Diffusers model outperforms the other methods, particularly for larger puzzle sizes.

caption: Table 2: Results (averaged over 5 runs) on the four-digit MNIST sorting benchmark.
description: This table presents the results of the four-digit MNIST sorting benchmark, comparing three different methods: DiffSort [34], Error-free DiffSort [20], and Symmetric Diffusers (the proposed model).  The metrics used are Kendall-Tau (a measure of rank correlation), Accuracy (percentage of perfectly sorted images), and Correct (percentage of correctly placed digits). The results are shown for different sequence lengths (number of digits to sort), ranging from 3 to 100.  The table demonstrates the performance of each method as the difficulty of the sorting task increases.

caption: Table 3: Ablation study on transitions of reverse diffusion and decoding strategies. Results are averaged over three runs on sorting 52 four-digit MNIST images.
description: This table presents the results of an ablation study conducted to evaluate the impact of different reverse diffusion transitions and decoding strategies on the performance of the SymmetricDiffusers model.  Specifically, it compares the performance using different combinations of generalized Plackett-Luce (GPL) distribution, Plackett-Luce (PL) distribution and inverse riffle shuffle (IRS) for the reverse diffusion, along with greedy search and beam search for decoding. The results are averaged over three runs using 52 four-digit MNIST images for sorting.

caption: Table 4: Results on TSP-20. * means we remove the post-processing heuristics for a fair comparison.
description: This table presents the results of applying various methods to solve the Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP) with 20 nodes.  It compares the performance of several established Operations Research (OR) solvers (Gurobi, Concorde, LKH-3, and 2-Opt) against a graph convolutional network (GCN) and a diffusion-based method (DIFUSCO), as well as the proposed SymmetricDiffusers model. The metrics used are the total tour length (lower is better) and the optimality gap (percentage difference from the optimal solution, also lower is better). The * indicates that post-processing heuristics were removed from the compared methods to ensure a fair comparison.

caption: Table 5: More results on sorting the 4-digit MNIST dataset using different combinations of forward process methods and reverse process methods. Results averaged over 3 runs with different seeds. RS: riffle shuffle; GPL: generalized Plackett-Luce; IRS: inverse riffle shuffle; RT: random transposition; IT: inverse transposition; RI: random insertion; II: inverse insertion.
description: This table presents additional results on the 4-digit MNIST sorting task, exploring various combinations of forward and reverse diffusion processes, including different shuffling methods and their inverses.  It examines the impact of these choices on the model's performance as measured by Kendall-Tau correlation, accuracy, and correctness. The results are averaged across three runs, demonstrating how the selection of shuffling methods and their inverse significantly affects model accuracy.
section: 3.4 Denoising Schedule via Merging Reverse Steps

caption: Table 6: Results of sorting 100 4-digit MNIST images using various denoising schedules with the combination of RS, GPL and beam search consistently applied.
description: This table presents an ablation study on the impact of different denoising schedules on the performance of the SymmetricDiffusers model for the task of sorting 100 four-digit MNIST images.  The results show Kendall-Tau correlation, accuracy (percentage of perfectly sorted images), and correctness (percentage of correctly placed digits).  The consistent application of RS (riffle shuffle) for the forward process, GPL (generalized Plackett-Luce) for the reverse process, and beam search for decoding are held constant across all experiments; only the denoising schedule is varied.
section: 3.4 Denoising Schedule via Merging Reverse Steps

caption: Table 1: Results (averaged over 5 runs) on solving the jigsaw puzzle on Noisy MNIST and CIFAR10.
description: This table shows the results of the jigsaw puzzle experiments on the Noisy MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets.  Five different methods are compared: Gumbel-Sinkhorn Network, DiffSort, Error-free DiffSort, and SymmetricDiffusers (the proposed model). The comparison is done across various puzzle sizes (2x2 to 6x6) and metrics (Kendall-Tau, Accuracy, Correct Percentage, RMSE, and MAE).  The results indicate the performance of each method in terms of correctly solving the jigsaw puzzle and the accuracy of the reassembled images.

caption: Table 8: Denoising schedules for the Jigsaw Puzzle task, where we use riffle shuffle in the forward process and GPL in the reverse process.
description: This table shows the denoising schedules used for the Jigsaw Puzzle task in the experiments.  The denoising schedule is a sequence of timesteps used in the reverse diffusion process to improve sampling and learning efficiency.  The table shows different schedules based on the number of patches per side (2x2 to 6x6) indicating that longer sequences benefit from more granular intermediate steps in the denoising schedule.

caption: Table 1: Results (averaged over 5 runs) on solving the jigsaw puzzle on Noisy MNIST and CIFAR10.
description: This table presents the results of the experiments conducted on solving jigsaw puzzles using the SymmetricDiffusers model.  It compares the performance of the proposed model against three other methods: Gumbel-Sinkhorn Network, DiffSort, and Error-free DiffSort. The comparison is done across different puzzle sizes (2x2, 3x3, 4x4) and datasets (Noisy MNIST and CIFAR-10).  The metrics used for evaluation include Kendall-Tau, accuracy (percentage of perfectly solved puzzles), correctness (percentage of correctly placed pieces), RMSE, and MAE.

caption: Table 10: Denoising schedules for the Sort 4-Digit MNIST Numbers task, where we use riffle shuffle in the forward process and GPL in the reverse process.
description: This table shows the denoising schedules used for the Sort 4-Digit MNIST Numbers experiment.  The denoising schedule specifies the timesteps at which reverse diffusion steps are performed. Different schedules are used for different sequence lengths (n). The forward process uses the riffle shuffle, and the reverse process utilizes the Generalized Plackett-Luce (GPL) distribution.

caption: Table 1: Results (averaged over 5 runs) on solving the jigsaw puzzle on Noisy MNIST and CIFAR-10.
description: This table presents the results of the jigsaw puzzle experiments on the Noisy MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets.  The results are averaged over five runs to provide a more reliable measure. The table compares the performance of SymmetricDiffusers with several state-of-the-art baselines using multiple metrics.  Metrics include Kendall-Tau (a measure of rank correlation), Accuracy (the percentage of correctly assembled images), Correctness (the percentage of correctly placed pieces), RMSE (root mean square error), and MAE (mean absolute error).  The results are shown for different puzzle sizes (2x2, 3x3, 4x4 for Noisy MNIST and 2x2, 3x3, 4x4 for CIFAR-10).

caption: Table 12: Hyperparameters for Error-Free Diffsort on Sorting 4-Digit MNIST Numbers
description: This table presents the hyperparameter settings used for the Error-Free Diffsort model when applied to the task of sorting 4-digit MNIST numbers.  It shows how the hyperparameters (Steepness, Sorting Network, Loss Weight, and Learning Rate) change with different sequence lengths (the number of 4-digit MNIST images to sort). Note the use of 'odd even' and 'bitonic' sorting networks, indicating different network architectures are used for varying sequence lengths.

caption: Table 13: Hyperparameters for Diffsort on Sorting 4-Digit MNIST Numbers
description: This table shows the hyperparameters used for the Diffsort model when training it on the task of sorting 4-digit MNIST numbers.  It specifies, for different sequence lengths (number of images to sort), the values for Steepness (a parameter of the Diffsort algorithm), and the type of Sorting Network (either 'odd even' or 'bitonic').  These hyperparameters were tuned for optimal performance on this specific task.
